questions.text: Damage to the structure producing the elevation marked leads to paralysis of which of the following muscle?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Risorius. The elevation marked refers to the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII), which innervates the risorius muscle. Damage to the structure producing this elevation would lead to paralysis of the risorius muscle, which is responsible for pulling the corners of the mouth laterally, creating a smile or a grin. The facial nerve controls all the muscles of facial expression, and its paralysis can result in the loss of movement in the muscles it innervates, including the risorius. Incorrect Responses: A. Lateral rectus The lateral rectus muscle is responsible for moving the eye laterally and is innervated by the abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI), not the facial nerve. Therefore, damage to the structure related to the facial nerve would not cause paralysis of the lateral rectus muscle. C. Levator palpebrae superioris The levator palpebrae superioris muscle is responsible for elevating the upper eyelid and is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III). Since this muscle is not controlled by the facial nerve, damage to the structure linked with facial nerve elevation would not lead to paralysis of the levator palpebrae superioris. D. Superior oblique The superior oblique muscle is involved in eye movement and is innervated by the trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV). Like the lateral rectus and levator palpebrae superioris, it is not under the control of the facial nerve, so damage to the facial nerve does not cause paralysis of the superior oblique muscle.

questions.text: Examine the following pic. Which of the following is damaged depending on these findings?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Abducent nerve. Based on the findings described, the patient is likely experiencing lateral rectus muscle paralysis, which would result in an inability to move the eye laterally (to the side). The abducent nerve (cranial nerve VI) innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for this eye movement. Damage to the abducent nerve results in horizontal diplopia (double vision) and an inability to abduct the eye, causing symptoms similar to those described in the question. Incorrect Responses: B. Facial nerve The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is primarily responsible for the muscles of facial expression and does not affect eye movement. Damage to the facial nerve would cause facial weakness or paralysis, such as an inability to smile or close the eyelids, but not double vision or impaired eye movement. Therefore, the facial nerve is not responsible for the symptoms described. C. Trochlear nerve The trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV) innervates the superior oblique muscle, which helps in downward and inward eye movement. Damage to this nerve typically results in difficulty looking down, especially when the eye is adducted, causing vertical diplopia. Since the symptoms described involve a problem with lateral eye movement, the trochlear nerve is not the correct answer. D. Oculomotor nerve The oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) controls most of the eye muscles, including the superior, inferior, and medial rectus, the inferior oblique, and the levator palpebrae superioris (responsible for elevating the eyelid). While damage to the oculomotor nerve could cause ptosis (drooping eyelid) and inability to move the eye in certain directions, it would not specifically cause a loss of lateral movement, which is controlled by the abducent nerve. Therefore, the oculomotor nerve is not the correct answer for the symptoms described.

choices.text: Deep petrosal nerve + greater petrosal nerve

questions.text: Nerve to pterygoid canal/ vidian nerve is formed by :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Deep petrosal nerve + greater petrosal nerve The nerve to the pterygoid canal, also known as the Vidian nerve, is formed by the combination of the deep petrosal nerve and the greater petrosal nerve. The greater petrosal nerve, which carries parasympathetic fibers from the facial nerve (CN VII), joins with the deep petrosal nerve, which contains sympathetic fibers from the internal carotid plexus. Together, they form the Vidian nerve, which travels through the pterygoid canal to provide autonomic innervation to the pterygopalatine ganglion and its branches. Incorrect Answers: B. Facial nerve The facial nerve (CN VII) contributes to the formation of the greater petrosal nerve, but it is not the direct source of the Vidian nerve itself. The facial nerve gives rise to the greater petrosal nerve, which then joins the deep petrosal nerve to form the Vidian nerve. Therefore, the facial nerve is indirectly involved but is not the answer to the question. C. Lesser superficial petrosal nerve The lesser superficial petrosal nerve is a separate nerve that carries parasympathetic fibers from the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) to the otic ganglion, which is involved in the parasympathetic innervation of the parotid gland. It does not contribute to the formation of the Vidian nerve, so this option is incorrect. D. Lesser petrosal nerve The lesser petrosal nerve, which originates from the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), also does not form the Vidian nerve. It primarily innervates the otic ganglion and is involved in parasympathetic innervation to the parotid gland. It is not related to the formation of the Vidian nerve,

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding the oculomotor nerve are true except -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) It innervates lateral rectus. The oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) does not innervate the lateral rectus muscle. The lateral rectus muscle, responsible for moving the eye laterally, is innervated by the abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI). The oculomotor nerve is responsible for innervating most of the extraocular muscles, including the medial rectus, superior rectus, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique, but it does not innervate the lateral rectus muscle. This makes option C incorrect. Incorrect Options: A. It accommodates the eye: The oculomotor nerve plays a role in the accommodation reflex, which is the ability of the eye to focus on near objects. This function involves the parasympathetic fibers of the oculomotor nerve, which innervate the ciliary muscle and cause the lens to become more convex. This statement is true. B. It raises the upper eyelid: The oculomotor nerve innervates the levator palpebrae superioris muscle, which is responsible for raising the upper eyelid. Damage to the oculomotor nerve can lead to ptosis, or drooping of the eyelid, making this statement true as well. D. It constricts the pupil: The parasympathetic fibers of the oculomotor nerve also control the constriction of the pupil through innervation of the sphincter pupillae muscle. This action is part of the pupillary light reflex. This statement is also true.

questions.text: All are seen in 3rd nerve palsy except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Miosis. In third nerve palsy (oculomotor nerve palsy), miosis (constriction of the pupil) is not typically seen. Instead, third nerve palsy usually results in mydriasis (dilation of the pupil) due to the loss of parasympathetic innervation that controls the constriction of the pupil. The third nerve is responsible for controlling most of the eye muscles, including the sphincter pupillae, which causes pupil constriction. When the oculomotor nerve is damaged, the pupil becomes dilated, and it is unresponsive to light (a condition known as a "fixed" dilated pupil). Therefore, miosis would not be observed in third nerve palsy, making it the exception. Incorrect Options: A. Mydriasis: Mydriasis (pupil dilation) is a hallmark of third nerve palsy. Since the oculomotor nerve is responsible for constricting the pupil via parasympathetic fibers, damage to this nerve causes the pupil to remain dilated because the constrictor muscles of the iris no longer function properly. This is a common finding in third nerve palsy, making mydriasis a correct feature. B. Ptosis: Ptosis (drooping of the eyelid) is another typical sign of third nerve palsy. The oculomotor nerve innervates the levator palpebrae superioris muscle, which raises the eyelid. Damage to the third nerve causes weakness or paralysis of this muscle, leading to ptosis. This is a well-known feature of third nerve palsy. C. Outward deviation of eye: Outward deviation of the eye (also called "exotropia") is a result of third nerve palsy because the oculomotor nerve controls most of the extraocular muscles, including the medial rectus, which is responsible for adducting (moving inward) the eye. When the oculomotor nerve is impaired, the unopposed action of the lateral rectus (innervated by the abducens nerve) causes the eye to deviate outward. This is a common symptom of third nerve palsy.

questions.text: Cranial nerve emerging between pyramidal and olive eminence is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 12th CN (Hypoglossal nerve). The 12th cranial nerve (hypoglossal nerve) emerges from the brainstem between the pyramidal and olive eminences. It exits the medulla oblongata, specifically in the groove between the pyramidal tract (which carries motor fibers to the body) and the olive (a structure involved in motor coordination). The hypoglossal nerve is responsible for motor innervation to the muscles of the tongue, except for the palatoglossus, which is innervated by the vagus nerve. This makes the hypoglossal nerve the correct answer to the question. Incorrect Options: A. 6th CN (Abducens nerve): The 6th cranial nerve (abducens nerve) emerges from the pons at the junction of the pons and medulla, and it innervates the lateral rectus muscle of the eye to control lateral movement. It does not emerge between the pyramidal and olive eminences, making it an incorrect answer. B. 7th CN (Facial nerve): The 7th cranial nerve (facial nerve) emerges from the pons, in close association with the 8th cranial nerve (vestibulocochlear nerve), but it does not exit between the pyramidal and olive eminences. Instead, the facial nerve passes through the internal auditory meatus and travels to innervate the muscles of facial expression, making this option incorrect. C. 11th CN (Accessory nerve): The 11th cranial nerve (accessory nerve) arises from the spinal cord and the medulla. It innervates the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles. It emerges laterally from the medulla and the upper cervical spinal cord, but not between the pyramidal and olive eminences, making this option incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following is not the feature of Horner’s syndrome
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Mydriasis Mydriasis (dilation of the pupil) is not a feature of Horner’s syndrome. Horner's syndrome is caused by disruption of the sympathetic nerve pathway to the eye, leading to a constellation of symptoms. One of the hallmark features of Horner's syndrome is miosis (constriction of the pupil), not mydriasis. This occurs due to a loss of sympathetic innervation to the dilator pupillae muscle, which causes the pupil to constrict. Therefore, mydriasis is not associated with Horner’s syndrome, making option C the correct answer. Incorrect Answers: A. Ptosis Ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid) is a common feature of Horner’s syndrome. It occurs due to paralysis of the sympathetic fibers that innervate the superior tarsal muscle (Müller's muscle), which is responsible for maintaining eyelid elevation. Therefore, ptosis is a characteristic sign of Horner's syndrome, making option A incorrect. B. Miosis Miosis (constriction of the pupil) is one of the classic features of Horner’s syndrome. It results from the loss of sympathetic stimulation to the dilator pupillae muscle, causing the pupil to become smaller. Miosis is a hallmark of Horner’s syndrome, making option B incorrect. D. Anhydrosis Anhydrosis (lack of sweating) is another feature of Horner’s syndrome. It occurs due to the disruption of sympathetic innervation to the sweat glands on the affected side of the face. This results in the inability to sweat properly on that side, contributing to the syndrome's characteristic signs. Therefore, anhydrosis is part of Horner’s syndrome, making option D incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following is the site of cerebellar input?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Inferior olivary nuclei The inferior olivary nuclei are a key site of cerebellar input. They send signals to the cerebellum via the olivocerebellar tract, which plays a crucial role in motor coordination. The inferior olivary nuclei provide input to the cerebellum about motor movements, including feedback for motor learning and fine-tuning of voluntary movements. This input is essential for the cerebellum's role in maintaining balance, posture, and smooth coordination of movement. Incorrect Answers: B. Vestibular nuclei The vestibular nuclei are involved in maintaining balance and coordinating head movements, and they do send some input to the cerebellum, particularly through the vestibulocerebellar pathway. However, they are more involved in processing sensory information related to balance and spatial orientation rather than being a primary site of cerebellar input, making this option less precise for the question. C. Globose and emboliform nuclei The globose and emboliform nuclei are part of the cerebellum's deep nuclei, which process cerebellar output rather than input. These nuclei receive input from the cerebellar cortex and relay motor information to other parts of the brain, but they do not serve as primary sources of cerebellar input themselves. Therefore, this option is incorrect. D. Dentate nucleus The dentate nucleus, like the globose and emboliform nuclei, is another cerebellar deep nucleus. It primarily deals with the output from the cerebellum, especially in the coordination of voluntary movements. It is not a site of input to the cerebellum, which is why this option is incorrect.

questions.text: The cranial nerve with the longest intracranial course -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) Trochlear The trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV) has the longest intracranial course among the cranial nerves. It is unique in that it is the only cranial nerve that originates from the dorsal aspect of the brainstem (midbrain). After exiting the midbrain, it travels a long intracranial route around the brainstem before entering the orbit. This extended pathway within the cranial cavity makes the trochlear nerve the longest intracranial nerve. Therefore, option E is correct. Incorrect Answers: A. Optic The optic nerve (cranial nerve II) is responsible for vision and travels from the retina to the brain. It does not have as long an intracranial course as the trochlear nerve because the optic nerve is primarily confined to the region from the eye to the optic chiasm and does not extend far into the cranial cavity. Therefore, option A is incorrect. B. Abducent The abducent nerve (cranial nerve VI) is responsible for controlling the lateral rectus muscle of the eye. Although it has a relatively long intracranial course compared to some other cranial nerves, it does not exceed the length of the trochlear nerve’s pathway. It travels through the cavernous sinus and exits the skull via the superior orbital fissure. Thus, option B is incorrect. C. Trigeminal The trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) is a large nerve responsible for sensation in the face and motor functions related to chewing. While it has an extensive course through the brainstem, its intracranial portion is not as long as that of the trochlear nerve, as it branches relatively early into its three divisions (ophthalmic, maxillary, and mandibular). Therefore, option C is incorrect. D. Oculomotor The oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) controls most of the eye muscles, but its intracranial course is shorter compared to the trochlear nerve. It exits the midbrain and passes through the cavernous sinus to enter the orbit. Though it has a significant role in eye movement, it does not travel a longer distance than the trochlear nerve within the cranial cavity.

questions.text: Cranial nerve that lies between superior cerebellar artery and posterior cerebral artery is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Oculomotor nerve The oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) lies between the superior cerebellar artery and the posterior cerebral artery as it passes through the interpeduncular fossa. The superior cerebellar artery is located above the oculomotor nerve, while the posterior cerebral artery is located below it, and the oculomotor nerve runs between them. This anatomical relationship is important in understanding the vascular supply to the brainstem and its implications for cranial nerve function. Therefore, option A is correct. Incorrect Answers: B. Optic nerve The optic nerve (cranial nerve II) is not located between the superior cerebellar artery and the posterior cerebral artery. Instead, the optic nerve is found along the base of the brain, near the optic chiasm, and is primarily associated with the anterior circulation of the brain, particularly the ophthalmic arteries. Therefore, option B is incorrect. C. Abducens nerve The abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI) emerges from the brainstem at the pons, traveling in a different anatomical location from the oculomotor nerve. It is more inferior and closer to the clivus and petrous part of the temporal bone, and is not situated between the superior cerebellar artery and posterior cerebral artery. Therefore, option C is incorrect. D. Trigeminal nerve The trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) exits from the pons but does not lie between the superior cerebellar artery and the posterior cerebral artery. It emerges laterally from the pons, and its branches are primarily responsible for sensory innervation of the face and motor innervation for mastication.

questions.text: The Thinnest cranial nerve is the -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Trochlear. Explanation: The trochlear nerve (Cranial nerve IV) is the thinnest cranial nerve. It is unique because it is the only cranial nerve that arises from the dorsal aspect of the brainstem (midbrain) and it innervates the superior oblique muscle of the eye. Despite its important function in controlling eye movement, the trochlear nerve is the thinnest and most fragile of all cranial nerves. Its small size contributes to its vulnerability to damage, often resulting in double vision or difficulty with certain eye movements when injured. Incorrect responses: A. Olfactory: The olfactory nerve (Cranial nerve I) is responsible for the sense of smell. It is not the thinnest cranial nerve, although it is also a relatively small nerve. The olfactory nerve is unique in that it is composed of several small nerve fibers that pass through the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone to reach the olfactory bulb. B. Oculomotor: The oculomotor nerve (Cranial nerve III) is responsible for the movement of most of the eye muscles, including the eyelid. It is thicker and larger compared to the trochlear nerve because it has to innervate multiple muscles, including the levator palpebrae superioris and extraocular muscles. The oculomotor nerve also carries parasympathetic fibers to the pupil constrictor muscles. D. Accessory: The accessory nerve (Cranial nerve XI) is primarily responsible for innervating the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles, which control head and shoulder movements. Although it is an important nerve, it is much thicker than the trochlear nerve and not the thinnest cranial nerve.

questions.text: All the muscles of the face are supplied by facial nerve except –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Levator palpebrae superioris. Explanation: The Levator palpebrae superioris is not supplied by the facial nerve. This muscle is responsible for elevating the upper eyelid and is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (CN III). It is the only muscle of the face listed here that is not innervated by the facial nerve, which is responsible for the motor control of facial muscles. Incorrect responses: A. Levator anguli oris: This muscle is innervated by the facial nerve. It is involved in elevating the corners of the mouth, contributing to facial expressions like smiling. B. Corrugator supercilli: The facial nerve also innervates the corrugator supercilli, a muscle responsible for drawing the eyebrows together, which is important for expressions such as frowning. D. Risorius: The risorius is a muscle that helps in smiling or grinning and is also innervated by the facial nerve. It draws the corners of the mouth laterally.

questions.text: Cranial accessory nerve supplies
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Soft palate. Explanation: The cranial accessory nerve (also known as accessory nerve, CN XI) has both cranial and spinal roots. The cranial part of the accessory nerve is responsible for innervating muscles of the soft palate, pharynx, and larynx. Specifically, it supplies the levator veli palatini (muscle responsible for elevating the soft palate) and other muscles involved in swallowing and speech. The cranial root of the accessory nerve joins the vagus nerve (CN X) to innervate the soft palate, making this option correct. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Sternomastoid The sternomastoid (or sternocleidomastoid) muscle is innervated by the spinal root of the accessory nerve (CN XI), not the cranial root. The spinal part of the accessory nerve innervates the sternomastoid and trapezius muscles (option B). So, while the accessory nerve does innervate the sternomastoid, the correct answer here specifically refers to the cranial part of the nerve, which supplies the soft palate. B. Trapezius The trapezius muscle is also innervated by the spinal part of the accessory nerve, not the cranial part. The spinal accessory nerve innervates both the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles, which are involved in head and shoulder movements. C. Splenius capitis The splenius capitis muscle is a deep muscle of the neck that is innervated by the cervical spinal nerves (C3-C5), not the accessory nerve. It helps in head rotation and extension, but it is not related to the cranial accessory nerve.

choices.text: Arises from dorsal aspect of brain
Descends between anterior and middle cerebral arteries
Damage causes ipsilateral superior oblique muscle palsy
Nucleus located in caudal mesencephalon below cerebral aqueduct

questions.text: False regarding trochlear nerve?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Descends between anterior and middle cerebral arteries. Explanation: The trochlear nerve (Cranial Nerve IV) is unique in that it is the only cranial nerve that arises from the dorsal aspect of the brainstem, specifically from the caudal mesencephalon (midbrain), just below the level of the cerebral aqueduct. It innervates the superior oblique muscle of the eye, which helps with downward and lateral eye movement. Option B is incorrect because the trochlear nerve does not descend between the anterior and middle cerebral arteries. In fact, it exits the brainstem from the dorsal surface, loops around the brainstem, and travels to the superior oblique muscle without passing between these arteries. This anatomical detail is specific to the oculomotor nerve, which has a different path. Why the other options are correct: A. Arises from dorsal aspect of brain This is true. The trochlear nerve arises from the dorsal aspect of the brainstem, specifically from the caudal midbrain, which is unique among the cranial nerves. C. Damage causes ipsilateral superior oblique muscle palsy This is correct. Damage to the trochlear nerve can lead to palsy of the superior oblique muscle, causing symptoms such as diplopia (double vision) and difficulty looking downward, particularly when the eye is turned inward. D. Nucleus located in caudal mesencephalon below cerebral aqueduct This is correct. The trochlear nerve's nucleus is located in the caudal mesencephalon, below the level of the cerebral aqueduct. This is the lowest of the cranial nerve nuclei in the brainstem.

questions.text: Features of trigeminal nerve injury include all except ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Weakness in blowing whistle. Explanation: The trigeminal nerve (CN V) is responsible for sensory innervation to the face and motor innervation to the muscles of mastication. Injury to the trigeminal nerve can cause various sensory and motor deficits, but it does not directly cause weakness in blowing a whistle. Blowing a whistle typically involves the action of the orbicularis oris muscle, which is innervated by the facial nerve (CN VII), not the trigeminal nerve. Therefore, weakness in blowing a whistle is not a feature of trigeminal nerve injury, making it the correct answer in this case. Why the other options are correct: A. Loss of corneal reflex The corneal reflex involves the trigeminal nerve for the sensory component (via the ophthalmic branch, V1) and the facial nerve for the motor component (via the facial nerve's innervation to the orbicularis oculi). Injury to the trigeminal nerve can result in a loss of the sensory input to the corneal reflex, causing the loss of the reflex when the cornea is touched. This is a characteristic feature of trigeminal nerve injury. B. Weakness in closure of jaw The motor component of the trigeminal nerve innervates the muscles responsible for mastication, including the masseter, temporalis, and pterygoid muscles. Injury to the trigeminal nerve can lead to weakness or paralysis of these muscles, resulting in difficulty closing the jaw. This is a classic symptom of trigeminal nerve injury. D. Sensory loss of face The trigeminal nerve provides sensory innervation to the face through its three branches: the ophthalmic (V1), maxillary (V2), and mandibular (V3) branches. Injury to the trigeminal nerve can cause sensory loss in one or more regions of the face, depending on which branch is affected. This is another characteristic feature of trigeminal nerve injury.

questions.text: Facial N. supply all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Parotid gland. Explanation: The facial nerve (CN VII) is responsible for the motor innervation of all the muscles of facial expression. Additionally, it provides parasympathetic innervation to several glands, including the lacrimal gland, nasal glands, and submandibular gland. However, the parotid gland is not supplied by the facial nerve. Instead, the parotid gland is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), specifically through the otic ganglion, which provides parasympathetic fibers to the gland. Why the other options are incorrect: Lacrimal gland (Option A) The lacrimal gland is supplied by the facial nerve (CN VII) via the greater petrosal nerve, which carries parasympathetic fibers. These fibers synapse in the pterygopalatine ganglion and then travel to the lacrimal gland to stimulate tear production. Therefore, the facial nerve does supply the lacrimal gland, making this option incorrect. Nasal gland (Option B) The nasal glands also receive parasympathetic innervation from the facial nerve (CN VII). The greater petrosal nerve, a branch of the facial nerve, provides parasympathetic fibers that innervate the mucous glands in the nasal cavity via the pterygopalatine ganglion. Thus, the facial nerve supplies the nasal glands, making this option incorrect. Submandibular gland (Option C) The submandibular gland is innervated by the facial nerve (CN VII) through the chorda tympani branch, which carries parasympathetic fibers. These fibers synapse in the submandibular ganglion, and the postganglionic fibers then stimulate secretion from the submandibular gland. Therefore, the facial nerve does supply the submandibular gland, making this option incorrect.

questions.text: Cranial part Accessory nerve supplies all palatal muscles except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Tensor veli palatini. Explanation: The cranial part of the accessory nerve (also known as the spinal accessory nerve, CN XI) innervates most of the palatal muscles, including palatoglossus, palatopharyngeus, and levator veli palatini. However, the tensor veli palatini is not innervated by the accessory nerve. Instead, it is innervated by the mandibular nerve (V3), which is a branch of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V). This is the key reason why tensor veli palatini is the correct answer. Why the other options are incorrect: Palatoglossus (Option A) The palatoglossus is innervated by the cranial part of the accessory nerve via the vagus nerve (CN X). This muscle is involved in elevating the back of the tongue during swallowing and is one of the palatal muscles innervated by the accessory nerve, making it an incorrect choice for this question. Palatopharyngeus (Option B) The palatopharyngeus muscle is also innervated by the cranial part of the accessory nerve via the vagus nerve (CN X). It helps in elevating the pharynx during swallowing, and like the palatoglossus, it is a palatal muscle supplied by the accessory nerve, so this option is also incorrect. Levator veli palatini (Option D) The levator veli palatini is another palatal muscle innervated by the cranial part of the accessory nerve via the vagus nerve (CN X). It plays a key role in elevating the soft palate to close off the nasopharynx during swallowing, making it another incorrect answer for this question.

questions.text: Skin over the angle of mandible and parotid area is supplied by –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Greater auricular nerve. Explanation: The greater auricular nerve is a branch of the cervical plexus (C2 and C3) and supplies sensation to the skin over the angle of the mandible and the parotid area. It provides sensory innervation to the skin around the external ear, including the area over the angle of the mandible and the parotid gland. This nerve is important for sensation in this region of the face. Why the other options are incorrect: Posterior auricular nerve (Option B) The posterior auricular nerve is a branch of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) and provides motor innervation to the muscles around the ear, such as the auricular muscles. It does not supply the skin over the angle of the mandible or the parotid area. It is more involved in the sensory innervation of the ear and the scalp behind the ear. Auriculotemporal nerve (Option C) The auriculotemporal nerve is a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3), part of the trigeminal nerve. It primarily provides sensory innervation to the skin of the temple, anterior auricle, and external acoustic meatus. It does not supply the skin over the angle of the mandible or parotid area, which is the domain of the greater auricular nerve. Facial nerve (Option D) The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is responsible for the motor innervation of the muscles of facial expression. It does not provide sensory innervation to the skin over the angle of the mandible or the parotid area, which are supplied by the greater auricular nerve. The facial nerve also has some other sensory functions, but they are not related to the skin over these areas.

questions.text: Which of the cranial nerve decussate within the brain-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Trochlear. Explanation: The trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV) is the only cranial nerve that decussates (crosses over) within the brain. Specifically, the trochlear nerve's motor fibers cross in the midbrain before exiting the brainstem. This decussation means that the right trochlear nerve controls the left superior oblique muscle of the eye, and the left trochlear nerve controls the right superior oblique muscle. This is unique among cranial nerves and is important for coordinated eye movements. Why the other options are incorrect: Optic (Option B) The optic nerve (cranial nerve II) does not decussate entirely within the brain. However, a portion of the fibers of the optic nerve decussate at the optic chiasm, but this is only for the fibers from the nasal retina, not the entire nerve. This partial decussation is different from the complete decussation seen in the trochlear nerve. Oculomotor (Option C) The oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) does not decussate. It exits the brainstem and innervates the muscles that move the eye without crossing over to the opposite side. Therefore, the oculomotor nerve does not decussate within the brain. Trigeminal (Option D) The trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) does not decussate within the brain in the same way that the trochlear nerve does. While sensory fibers from the trigeminal nerve may cross to the opposite side in the brainstem, the motor fibers involved in mastication are not involved in decussation in the same manner.

questions.text: Trigeminal nerve has how many nuclei in CNS –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Four. Explanation: The trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) has four nuclei in the central nervous system (CNS), which are involved in different functions. These nuclei are: Mesencephalic nucleus: Responsible for proprioception from the muscles of mastication and other facial structures. Principal sensory nucleus: Involved in discriminative touch and pressure sensation from the face. Spinal trigeminal nucleus: Responsible for pain and temperature sensations from the face. Motor nucleus: Controls the muscles of mastication and some other muscles, such as the tensor tympani and mylohyoid muscles. These four nuclei are spread along the brainstem and are responsible for the diverse sensory and motor functions of the trigeminal nerve. Why the other options are incorrect: Three (Option A) The trigeminal nerve has four nuclei, not three. This makes Option A incorrect. The four nuclei encompass the sensory and motor functions of the nerve. Five (Option C) The trigeminal nerve has only four nuclei, so Option C is incorrect. While it may seem logical due to the multiple sensory functions, the nerve only has four distinct nuclei in the CNS. Six (Option D) Again, the trigeminal nerve only has four nuclei, so Option D is also incorrect. The trigeminal nerve does not have six nuclei, and this choice does not reflect the actual anatomy of the nerve.

questions.text: Lacrimal gland is supplied which of the following ganglia –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Sphenopalatine ganglion. Explanation: The lacrimal gland is supplied by the sphenopalatine ganglion (also called the pterygopalatine ganglion). The parasympathetic fibers for lacrimal gland secretion originate from the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII), which synapse in the sphenopalatine ganglion. After synapsing, the postganglionic fibers travel along the lacrimal nerve, a branch of the maxillary nerve (V2), to reach the lacrimal gland. The sphenopalatine ganglion plays a crucial role in the secretion of tears by the lacrimal gland. Why the other options are incorrect: Otic ganglion (Option A) The otic ganglion is involved in the parasympathetic innervation of the parotid gland, which is responsible for saliva production, not the lacrimal gland. It receives preganglionic fibers from the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX). Therefore, the otic ganglion is not associated with the lacrimal gland. Ciliary ganglion (Option B) The ciliary ganglion is responsible for the parasympathetic innervation of the eye, particularly the iris and the ciliary body, controlling pupil constriction and accommodation. It is not involved in lacrimal gland secretion, so it is not the correct answer. Submandibular ganglion (Option D) The submandibular ganglion is responsible for parasympathetic innervation to the submandibular and sublingual glands, which are involved in salivation. It is not associated with the lacrimal gland, so it is not the correct choice.

questions.text: First branch of Facial nerve is-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Greater superficial petrosal N. Explanation: The greater superficial petrosal nerve is the first branch of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). It arises from the facial nerve after it exits the brainstem and travels towards the geniculate ganglion. This nerve carries parasympathetic fibers and provides secretomotor innervation to the lacrimal gland, as well as to the mucosal glands of the nose and palate. It plays a crucial role in the secretion of tears and mucus. Therefore, the greater superficial petrosal nerve is the first branch of the facial nerve. Why the other options are incorrect: Chorda tympani (Option A) The chorda tympani is a branch of the facial nerve, but it is not the first. It arises after the greater superficial petrosal nerve, traveling through the middle ear to innervate the submandibular and sublingual glands (secretomotor) and provides taste sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Therefore, it is not the first branch of the facial nerve. Nerve to stapedius (Option B) The nerve to stapedius is another branch of the facial nerve that arises within the facial canal. However, it is not the first branch. It innervates the stapedius muscle, which is involved in dampening the vibrations of the stapes bone in the middle ear. It follows the greater superficial petrosal and chorda tympani branches, making it an incorrect answer for the first branch. Lesser superficial petrosal N (Option C) The lesser superficial petrosal nerve is a branch that arises from the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX), not the facial nerve. It carries parasympathetic fibers to the parotid gland and is involved in secretion of saliva. Since it does not originate from the facial nerve, it is not the correct answer.

questions.text: The following are supplied by XII cranial nerve except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Palatoglossus. Explanation: The palatoglossus muscle is not supplied by the hypoglossal nerve (cranial nerve XII). Instead, it is innervated by the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) via the pharyngeal plexus. This is a key exception among the muscles of the tongue, as all other tongue muscles (both intrinsic and extrinsic) are innervated by the hypoglossal nerve. The palatoglossus muscle plays a role in elevating the posterior part of the tongue and narrowing the oropharyngeal isthmus during swallowing, making its innervation part of the broader function of the vagus nerve in coordinating swallowing and speech. Why the other options are incorrect: Genioglossus (Option B) The genioglossus muscle is supplied by the hypoglossal nerve. It is a major extrinsic muscle of the tongue that helps in protruding, depressing, and retracting the tongue. Its function is critical for tongue movements, including those involved in speech, swallowing, and maintaining an open airway. Hypoglossus (Option C) The hypoglossus muscle is also innervated by the hypoglossal nerve. It functions to depress and retract the tongue, playing a role in controlling tongue position and movement for speech and swallowing. None (Option D) This option implies that all listed muscles are innervated by the hypoglossal nerve, which is incorrect. The palatoglossus muscle is not innervated by the hypoglossal nerve but by the vagus nerve,

questions.text: The diagram represents which ligament complex ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (b)

questions.text: Examine the following pic. Which of the following is damaged depending on these findings?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Right lateral rectus isn’t working so Correct Answerwer is (Right) Abducent nerve injury

questions.text: Examine the following pic. Which of the following is damaged depending on these findings?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Left medial rectus isn’t working in rightward gaze but convergence is intact. So the lesion is in MLF. Its called MLF syndrome(internuclear ophthalmoplegia)

choices.text: Taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue
General sensation from the tonsillar lining
Salivary secretion from the submandibular gland

questions.text: The glossopharyngeal nerve is transected accidentally during a surgical procedure in a 45-year-old male. Which of the following is most likely lost in his patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) General sensation from the tonsillar lining is carried by IXth cranial nerve.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male presents to your office with difficulty walking. On physical examination, he has thoracic kyphoscoliosis. Also he has multiple small scars on his hands because he repeatedly accidentally burns his hands because he "cannot feel the heat." Neurologic examination reveals 1+ biceps reflexes and 3+ patellar reflexes bilaterally, as well as decreased muscle strength in the bilateral upper and lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's problems?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) This patient presents with both sensory and motor loss bilaterally. Only Syringomyelia can explain this. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis has only motor system involvement. Guillian-barre syndrome has predominantly motor involvement.

questions.text: A 55 years old man , a known case of syphilis complains of problems in walking such as with the legs far apart. Also on Examination, Loss of coordination and reflexes is observed.which of the following explains patients' condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tabes Dorsalis involves the Posterior column pathway which carries information for fine touch, conscious proprioception etc. Tabes dorsalis is seen as complication of syphilis.

questions.text: A man comes with aphasia, is unable to name things and repetition is poor. However, comprehension, fluency and articulation is unaffected. He is probably suffering from:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Because Comprehension and fluency is unaffected Wernicke area and Broca area are intact but repetition is poor which is because of loss of communication between the two areas. Therefore it is conduction aphasia.

choices.text: Decreased gag reflex on the left
Decreased salivation from the left submandibular and sublingual salivary glands
Deviation of the tongue to the left on protrusion
Inability to elevate the pharynx on the left during swallowing

questions.text: A patient is taken up for a carotid endarterectomy, during surgery patient’s left hypoglossal nerve is injured . Which of the following would most likely result from this injury?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The hypoglossal nerve is a pure motor nerve (general somatic efferent) to the intrinsic muscles of the tongue. If the nerve is damaged, denervation atrophy of the affected side will permit the intact musculature of the opposite side to operate unopposed, thereby protruding the tongue to the side of the injury.

questions.text: Special visceral efferent doesn’t have which of the following
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A,B,C-Nucleus ambiguous (9, 10, 11) and motor nucleus of 5th and 7th are known as special visceral efferent as they supplies the pharyngeal arches. Option D-Dorsal nucleus of 10th Nerve is parasympathetic component,hence it comes under general visceral efferent.

questions.text: A patient presents with drooping of angle of mouth and inability to blow. Which of the following nerve is involved in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-3rd nerve palsy leads to weakness of extraocular muscles. Option B-5th nerve palsy leads to weakness of muscles of mastication. Option C-drooping of angle of mouth and inability to blow is seen in 7th nerve palsy (BELL’S PALSY). Option D-9th nerve palsy leads to weakness of stylopharyneus and absence of gag reflex.

questions.text: Which of the following nerve supplies the marked structure in the given pic?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-CN 2 i.e,optic nerve is sensory and do notsupply any muscles. Option B-Labelling is on the superior oblique muscle [SO4] which is supplied by CN 4 as we can see it is present superiorly and it lies outside the cone formed by recti muscles. Option C-CN 3 i.e,oculomotor nerve supplies all extraocular muscles except lateral rectus and superior oblique. Option D-CN 6 i.e,abducent nerve supplies lateral rectus.

questions.text: Sequential arrangment of 8th nerve pathway from periphery to center: 1. Vestibular nerve 2. Superior olivary nucleus 3. Medial geniculate body 4. Cochlear nuclei 5. Lateral lemniscus 6. Inferior colliculus
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 1-4-2-5-6-3 Mnemonic for 8th nerve pathway is "Spiral CT SLIM 41,42" which is as follows:- •SPIRAL ORGAN OF CORTI •COCHLEAR NUCLEI •TRAPEZOID BODY •SUPERIOR OLIVARY NUCLEUS –CENTER FOF STAPEDIAL REFLEX •LATERAL LEMINISCUS •INFERIOR COLLICULUS •MEDIAL GENICULATE BODY •AREA 41,42 –primary auditory area

questions.text: Name of the marked cranial nerve
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Marked nerve is 6th Nerve i.e, Abducent nerve as it is arising at pontomedullary junction. Option B-Glossopharyngeal nerve arises lateral to olive,from the medulla. Option C-Facial nerve also arises from pontomedullary junction but it lies lateral to 6th nerve. Option D-Vestibulocochlear nerve also arises at pontomedullary junction but it lies lateral to 7th nerve.

questions.text: Spinal cord ends at what level in adults?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Spinal cord ends in Adults-at L1. Spinal cord ends in Infants –at L3. Piamater & Duramater will reach coccyx level. Arachnoid reaches upto S2 level. Dural sac is present upto S2 level.

questions.text: Medial Lemniscus is a continuation of?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Spinothalamic tract makes the spinal leminiscus. Option B,C-SpinoTectal tract and SpinoCerebellar tract do not form any lemniscus. Option D-Fasciculus gracilis is a part of dorsal column tract and it continues as Medial Lemniscus.

questions.text: Which of the following feature will be seen in Lesion of the marked structure
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Ataxia occurs because of cerebellar involvement . Option B-Vertigo occurs because of vestibular nucleus involvement . Option C-The given Swelling at anterior aspect of medulla is the pyramidal tract.If involved- it will lead to contralateral hemiplegia. Option D-Facial nerve palsy occurs because of involvement of facial nucleus

questions.text: Damage to the structure producing the elevation marked, leads to paralysis of which of the following muscle?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Lateral rectus is supplied by 6th nerve. Option B-The marked area shows Rhomboid fossa/ floor of 4th ventricle which has facial colliculus,which is a dilation produced by 7th Nerve.Injury to 7th nerve will lead to palsy of risorius muscle. Option C-Levator palpebrae Superioris is supplied by 3rd nerve. Option D-Superior oblique is supplied by 4th nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following sensation is not perceived by spinal nucleus of trigeminal nerve?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A,B,C-Pain,Touch and Temperature is perceived by spinal nucleus of trigeminal nerve. Option D-proprioception is perceived by Mesencephalic nucleus of trigeminal nerve.

questions.text: Purkinje fibers relay to which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) There are 3 layers in cerebellar cortex:- 1. Molecular - basket & stellate cells. 2. Purkinje –purkinje cells –they are connected to deep nuclei of cerebellum(dentate nuclei). 3. Granular layer Afferent fibers of 2 types – 1. Climbing fibers – come from olivary nucleus –connected directly to purkinje fibers. 2. Mossy fibers –connected indirectly to purkinje fibers.

questions.text: There is a Marked area in the given section. Fibers from here will relay in which nucleus?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Inferior olivary gives rise to climbing fibers. Option B-Labelled structure is middle cerebellar peduncle which Relays into fastigial nucleus [deep nuclei of cerebellum]. Option C-Red nucleus gives rise to rubrospinal tract. Option D-Tectum gives rise to tectospinal tract.

questions.text: Trigeminal spinal nucleus, second order neuron is for?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The trigeminal nerve is the fifth cranial nerve and is responsible for sensation in the face. The trigeminal nerve has three major branches: the ophthalmic nerve (V1), the maxillary nerve (V2), and the mandibular nerve (V3). In the trigeminal sensory pathway, sensory information from the face is carried by the trigeminal nerve to the trigeminal ganglion, which contains the cell bodies of the primary sensory neurons. From there, the sensory information is transmitted to the trigeminal nerve's central processes, which synapse in the trigeminal sensory nucleus located in the brainstem. The trigeminal sensory nucleus consists of three main parts: 1. The main sensory nucleus - which carries discriminative touch and conscious proprioception information. 2. The spinal trigeminal nucleus - which carries pain and temperature information. 3. The mesencephalic nucleus - which carries proprioceptive information from the muscles of mastication. In the trigeminal sensory pathway, the second-order neurons for pain and temperature information from the face are located in the spinal trigeminal nucleus. These second-order neurons receive input from the primary sensory neurons in the trigeminal ganglion and transmit the information to higher brain centers for processing and perception.

questions.text: Arrange the columns from Medial to lateral? 1) SVA 2) SVE 3) SSA 4) GSA
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) From Medial to lateral,the arrangement is as follows:- SVE-special visceral efferent SVA-special visceral afferent GSA-general somatic afferent SSA-special somatic afferent

questions.text: Arrange the structures from peripheral to central order in Auditory pathway? 1. Spiral ganglion 2. Cochlear nucleus 3. Inferior colliculus 4. Lateral lemniscus
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Auditory pathway can be remembered with Mnemonic as follows:-ECOLI MA Eight nerve from spiral ganglion Cochlear nucleus superior Olivary nucleus Lateral lemniscus Inferior colliculus Medial geniculate body Auditory cortex.
